name: Number of households affected by drought
source:
Report
Russell, T., Nicholas, C., & Bernhofen, M. (2024). Annual probability of extreme heat and drought events, derived from Lange et al 2020 [Data set]. Zenodo. 10.5281/zenodo.11582369

Responding to climate change impacts on human health
in Europe: focus on floods, droughts and water quality
EEA Report 3/2024 (chapter 3)
description: Population exposure is calculated as annual expected population directly exposed to the occurrence of extreme heat or drought events, assuming any population directly within the footprint of an event is exposed, but not otherwise taking any other risk-mitigating or -propagating factors into account.

name: Flood exposure
source:
Overview on indicators used to characterise flood vulnerability,
Moreira et al. (2021), https://doi.org/10.5194/nhess-21-1513-2021
Malgwi et al. (2020), https://doi.org/10.5194/nhess-20-2067-2020
Flood Risk Mapping Worldwide: A Flexible Methodology and Toolbox, Glas et al. (2019), https://doi.org/10.3390/w11112371
description: A high number of people living in flood prone areas shows a high exposure to flood risks. Could be completed with other indicators to assess the impacts of floods on people living in flood prone areas (in terms of socio-economic impacts).

name: Number of properties flooded per year (or per event)
source: Flood Risk Mapping Worldwide: A Flexible Methodology and Toolbox, Glas et al. (2019), https://doi.org/10.3390/w11112371
description: Climate change increases the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events such as floods. It can also change the location and timing of floods.

name: Number of businesses located in flooded areas
source:
The FloodFlash Commercial Risk Report (2022)
https://www.towergate.com/media/2388/ff-commercial-risk-report-2022-002.pdf
description: The share of all businesses or commercial properties in a region that are situated within flood risk zones.

name: Critical infrastructures in areas at risk from flooding
source:
Cataloging and Testing Flood Risk Management Measures to Increase the Resilience of Critical Infrastructure Networks (2024), https://doi.org/10.3390/smartcities7050117

Flood Risk Mapping Worldwide: A Flexible Methodology and Toolbox, Glas et al. (2019), https://doi.org/10.3390/w11112371

Geospatial assessment (GIS) of the locations of critical infrastructure and overlaying flood risk map to identify, which hospitals, health care centres, nursing homes and similar, fall within high-risk areas. QGIS plugins, for example Flood Risk and SAGA GIS can help analyse flood data and create risk maps).).

Plugins: https://plugins.qgis.org/plugins/Floodrisk/#plugin-about
description: Essential services, such as hospitals should be located outside of risk areas to prevent them from being damaged and/or destroyed from floods/coastal erosion. Could be completed with other indicators to assess the vulnerability (i.e. sensitivity and adaptive capacity)

name: Share of flood area in the city or region
source:
Flood Risk Mapping Worldwide: A Flexible Methodology and Toolbox, Glas et al. (2019), https://doi.org/10.3390/w11112371
QGIS plugins, for example Flood Risk and SAGA GIS can help analyse flood data and create risk maps

Plugins: https://plugins.qgis.org/plugins/Floodrisk/#plugin-about

name: Change in occurrence of vector-borne diseases
source:
https://atlas.ecdc.europa.eu/public/index.aspx

https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/observatory/evidence/health-effects/vector-borne-diseases

Paz, S., 2021, Climate change impacts on vector-borne diseases in Europe: risks, predictions and actions, The Lancet Regional Health - Europe 1, 100017. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.lanepe.2020.100017

Semenza, J.C., 2015, Prototype early warning systems for vector-borne diseases in Europe, International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health 12(6): 6333–6351. https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph120606333

Semenza, J.C. & Suk, J.E., 2018, Vector-borne diseases and climate change: a European perspective, FEMS Microbiology Letters 365(2), fnx244. https://doi.org/10.1093/femsle/fnx244
description: Climate change increases the areal distribution and probability of occurrence of many vector-borne diseases (carried by, e.g., ticks and mosquitos)

name: Change in climatic preconditions for vector-borne diseases
description: Climate change increases the areal distribution and probability of occurrence of many vector-borne diseases (carried by vectors such as ticks and mosquitos)

name: Location of abandoned lands
source: Reference: Salis et al. 2022, https://doi.org/10.3390/land11111942
description: Abandoned or mal-maintained land areas pose an increased wildfire risk.

name: Number of weather-related disruptions in traffic and transportation
source:
Gössling et al. 2023, https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11069-023-06054-2

Leviäkangas et al. 2013, https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.3141/2329-06

Elyoussoufi et al. 2023: https://doi.org/10.3390/meteorology2040028
description: Describes total number and possible trend, or can be combined with (even rough) location information. Extreme weather events, such as heavy rainfall, heatwaves or storms, can cause damage and disruptions. Certain weather events become more common with changing climate.

name: Reduced work productivity due to heat stress
source:
Costa, H. et al. (2024), “The heat is on: Heat stress, productivity and adaptation among firms”, OECD Economics Department Working Papers, No. 1828, OECD Publishing, Paris, https://doi.org/10.1787/19d94638-en.

"Heat stress, productivity and adaptation among firms" https://www.oecd.org/content/dam/oecd/en/publications/reports/2024/12/the-heat-is-on-heat-stress-productivity-and-adaptation-among-firms_07b86e8b/19d94638-en.pdf

"Working on a WARMER planet The impact of heat stress on labour productivity and decent work" https://www.ilo.org/sites/default/files/wcmsp5/groups/public/@dgreports/@dcomm/@publ/documents/publication/wcms_711919.pdf
description: Reduced work productivity due to heat stress	Increased warming and humidity can lead to reduced work productivity especially for outdoor activities.

name: Changes in human thermal comfort in urban environments
source: Di Napoli C., Barnard C., Prudhomme C., Cloke HL and Pappenberger F. (2020): Thermal comfort indices derived from ERA5 reanalysis. Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) Climate Data Store (CDS). DOI: 10.24381/cds.553b7518
description: Urban thermal comfort is a critical aspect of city livability, influenced by complex interactions between the built environment and meteorological factors. Urban design strategies, such as implementing cool materials and urban greenery, can impact thermal comfort

name: Excess hospitalizations and deaths during heatwaves
source:
Pattern and determinants of hospitalization during heat waves: an ecologic study: BMC Public Health. 2007 Aug 9;7:200. doi: 10.1186/1471-2458-7-200

The 2024 Europe report of the Lancet Countdown on health and climate change: unprecedented warming demands unprecedented action
van Daalen, Kim R et al.The Lancet Public Health, Volume 9, Issue 7, e495 - e522 https://www.thelancet.com/action/showCitFormats?doi=10.1016%2FS2468-2667%2824%2900055-0&pii=S2468-2667%2824%2900055-0

name: Losses of GDP in percentage per year due to extreme events
source:
The Fiscal Impact of Extreme Weather and Climate Events: Evidence for EU Countries
https://economy-finance.ec.europa.eu/system/files/2022-07/dp168_en.pdf
description: Annualized Disaster Losses as % of Local GDP:  The total economic losses from extreme events in a locality over a year, divided by the locality’s annual GDP, multiplied by 100.

name: Drought-related disturbances to agricultural livelihoods
source:
Annual Crop Yield Reduction: Measures the decrease in crop yields (tons/hectare or % change) during drought years compared to average or baseline years.
Source: Indicator-to-impact links to help improve agricultural drought preparedness in Thailand, Nat. Hazards Earth Syst. Sci., 23, 2419–2441, https://doi.org/10.5194/nhess-23-2419-2023, 2023.

Farm Business Profit/Loss: Assesses changes in farm income or profit margins attributable to drought events, often using outcome-based modeling systems
Source: Monitoring agricultural and economic drought: the Australian Agricultural Drought Indicators (AADI). https://doi.org/10.5194/egusphere-2024-3731

name: Number of disruptions in energy system due to heat and drought
source:
García-León, D., Casanueva, A., Standardi, G. et al. Current and projected regional economic impacts of heatwaves in Europe. Nat Commun 12, 5807 (2021). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-26050-z

Compound Climate and Infrastructure Events: How Electrical Grid Failure Alters Heat Wave Risk. Environ Sci Technol. 2021 Apr 30;55(10):6957–6964. doi: 10.1021/acs.est.1c00024
description: Number and/or distribution of weather-related disruptions. Can help understand, which weather-related events cause disruptions currently and does the changing climate increase/decrease the risk of occurrence.

name: Number of disruptions in energy system due to flooding
source:
Weather-related disruptions in and unavailabilty of power supply: https://www.umweltbundesamt.de/en/monitoring-on-das/cluster/energy-industry/ew-i-1/indicator#ew-i-1-weather-related-disruptions-in-power-supply-

Copernicus:
https://climate.copernicus.eu/esotc/2024/flooding
https://european-flood.emergency.copernicus.eu/efas_frontend/#/home
description: Number and/or distribution of weather-related disruptions. Can help understand, which weather-related events cause disruptions currently and does the changing climate increase/decrease the risk of occurrence.

name: Disruptions to population due to water scarcity
source:
Sources:
https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/indicators/use-of-freshwater-resources-in-europe-1
https://www.emwis.org/news-and-events/news/water-scarcity-in-europe-key-findings-from-the-eea

European Environment Agency (ed.) 2024: Europe's state of water 2024. The need for improved water resilience. EEA Report No 07/2024. Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union
https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/publications/europes-state-of-water-2024
description: Describing, for example, the number of days per year with water use regulation

name: Number of days with poor air quality due to wildfires
source:
Sources:
https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/metadata/indicators/wildfire-smoke-in-europe

Hänninen, R., et al., 2022, Daily surface concentration of fire-related PM2. 5 for 2003-2021, modelled by SILAM CTM when using the MODIS satellite data for the fire radiative power, Finnish Meteorological Institute [dataset]. https://doi.org/10.23728/fmi-b2share.a006840cce9340e8bf11e562bb8d396e

Orellano, Pablo, et al., 2020, Short-term exposure to particulate matter (PM10 and PM2. 5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and ozone (O3) and all-cause and cause-specific mortality: Systematic review and meta-analysis, Environment international 142, 105876.  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envint.2020.105876

Soares, J., M. Sofiev, and J. Hakkarainen, 2025, Uncertainties of wild-land fires emission in AQMEII phase 2 case study, Atmospheric Environment 115, 361-370. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.atmosenv.2015.01.068
description: Poor air quality worsens the effects of heat on people’s health.

name: Areas vulnerable to wildfires
source:
Wildfire Risk Index: Integrates fire danger (likelihood of fire due to weather and fuel conditions) with vulnerability (exposure of people, ecosystems, and assets).
Used at the pan-European scale to rank and map areas by wildfire risk
Source:
EFFIS - European Forest Fire Information System. https://forest-fire.emergency.copernicus.eu/

Pan-European wildfire risk assessment: https://data.effis.emergency.copernicus.eu/effis/reports-and-publications/effis-related-publications/The+Pan-European+wildfire+risk+assessment+report+2022.pdf

Global data-driven prediction of fire activity
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58097-6

Fire Weather Index (FWI): A meteorological index (e.g., the Canadian FWI) that assesses daily fire danger based on temperature, humidity, wind, and precipitation. Used to monitor current and projected fire danger across Europe
Sources:
https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/indicators/forest-fires-in-europe?activeAccordion=ecdb3bcf-bbe9-4978-b5cf-0b136399d9f8

Venäläinen, A., Korhonen, N., Hyvärinen, O., Koutsias, N., Xystrakis, F., Urbieta, I. R. and Moreno, J. M., 2014, 'Temporal variations and change in forest fire danger in Europe for 1960–2012', Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences 14(6), pp. 1477–1490 ( https://www.nat-hazards-earth-syst-sci.net/14/1477/2014/ ) accessed September 26, 2019

Mila, C., 2024 Wildfire smoke indicators for the Lancet Countdown Europe 2024 edition. https://github.com/carlesmila/LCDE2024_wildfires
description:
Global data-driven prediction of fire activity

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58097-7

name: Increase in soil degradation and desertification
source:
Panagos, P., Broothaerts, N., Ballabio, C., Orgiazzi, A., De Rosa, D., Borrelli, P., Liakos, L., Vieira, D., Van Eynde, E., Arias Navarro, C., Breure, T., Fendrich, A., Köninger, J., Labouyrie, M., Matthews, F., Muntwyler, A., Jimenez, J.M., Wojda, P., Yunta, F., Marechal, A., Sala, S., Jones, A., 2024. How the EU Soil Observatory is providing solid science for healthy soils. European Journal of Soil Science,  75(3), e13507. doi: 10.1111/ejss.13507

Panagos, P., Borrelli, P., Jones, A. and Robinson, D.A., 2024. A 1 billion euro mission: A Soil Deal for Europe. European Journal of Soil Science, 75(1), e13466.DOI: 10.1111/ejss.13466

EU Soil degradation dashbord: https://esdac.jrc.ec.europa.eu/esdacviewer/euso-dashboard/
description: Describes either future risk based on climate projections and possibly land use. And/or combines projections with local information on high-risk areas of soil degradation, increased erosion (including agricultural lands) and desertification due to, e.g., their current state, type of vegetation, activities such as agriculture or changes in land use.

name: Water usage rate in agriculture
source:
Total Water Abstraction for Agriculture:
- Eurostat – environment statistics - Table annual water abstraction by source and by sector (env_wat_abs), data water abstraction for irrigation purposes. Information on the share of water abstraction in agriculture (for irrigation purposes) as a percentage of the total gross (freshwater) abstraction is also available.
- Agro-environmental indicator (AEI) 20: Water abstraction, as defined in the COM (2006) 508 on "Development of agri-environmental indicators for monitoring the integration of environmental concerns into the CAP". http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Agri-environmental_indicator_-_water_abstraction

Agri-environmental indicator - irrigation
https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=Agri-environmental_indicator_-_irrigation#Data_sources

Additional sourceS: https://agridata.ec.europa.eu/Qlik_Downloads/InfoSheetEnvironmental/infoC39.html
description: Important indicator in understanding water needs and need for more efficient practices.

name: Change in the threat of pests and diseases harming agriculture/forestry
source:
Gullino et al. 2022: https://doi.org/10.3390/su141912421

Paini et al. 2016 (agricultural invasive species): https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1602205113

IPCC/FAO 2021: https://doi.org/10.4060/cb4769en
description: Changes in temperature and rainfall conditions can lead to changes in pests and pathogens with negative impacts on the timber industry and state of environment.

name: Annual timber losses from pests and pathogens
source:
Gullino et al. 2022: https://doi.org/10.3390/su141912421

Davies et al. 2017: https://doi.org/10.1093/forestry/cpaa025

van Hensbergen, H. & Cedergren, J. 2020: https://doi.org/10.4060/cb0686en
description: Changes in temperature and rainfall conditions can lead to changes in pests and pathogens with negative impacts on the timber industry and state of environment.

name: Damages in forests due to weather-related events
source:
Santopuoli et al. 2020: https://doi.org/10.1139/cjfr-2020-0166

van Hensbergen, H. & Cedergren, J. 2020: https://doi.org/10.4060/cb0686en
description: Describes the amount, percentage or areal distribution of weather-related damages and assesses the extent of harm inflicted on forest ecosystems resulting from extreme weather phenomena, such as storms, droughts, floods, and wildfires. This indicator is essential for understanding the vulnerability of forested areas to climate change. Certain forest types and species are more susceptible to weather-related damage, e.g., young or aging forests may lack the structural integrity to withstand severe storms, while invasive species can exacerbate the impact of climate stressors.

name: Total forest area impacted by wildfire per year
source: https://www.globalforestwatch.org/dashboards/global/?category=fires
description: Increasing temperature due to climate change can lead to increase wildfire with negative impactson forest resources, local populations and tourism.

name: Development of tools, guidelines, and policies to support action on climate risks
source:
Good practices for climaterelated and environmental risk management_European central Bank. Observations from the 2022. Thematic review. https://www.bankingsupervision.europa.eu/ecb/pub/pdf/ssm.thematicreviewcercompendiumgoodpractices112022~b474fb8ed0.en.pdf

UNEP Database: Sustainability Risk Tool Dashboard. https://www.unepfi.org/themes/climate-change/the-sustainability-risk-tool-dashboard/
description:
This indicator could be expanded to track various elements chosen, e.g.:
- number of tools, guides, policies developed
- number of users of such resources
- number of working groups or agencies involved in actions
- status of development (production, testing, issued, in use) of tools, guides, or policies
- etc.

name: Capacity building and awareness raising actions
source:
ECBI (2018). Pocket guide to capacity building for climate change.

Swart, R., J., and Singh, T., (2013). MEDIATION and the adaptation challenge: identifying appropriate methods and tools to support climate change adaptation decision making. Alterra, Wageningen UR, Wageningen, the Netherlands, p. 32.

Climate-Adapt_Capacity building on climate change adaptation: https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/metadata/adaptation-options/capacity-building-on-climate-change-adaptation

Developing Key Performance Indicators for Climate Change Adaptation and Resilience Planning: https://nicholasinstitute.duke.edu/sites/default/files/publications/developing-key-performance-indicators-for-climate-change-adaptation-and-resilience-planning.pdf
description:
This indicator can be expanded to include the chosen elements, e.g.:
- Number of staff or other target groups having received training on climate adaptation
- Number of trainings or campaigns conducted
- Number of stakeholders using and distributing climate information

name: Number of financial mechanisms identified to support climate change adaptation
source:
Climate Finance Thematic Briefing: Adaptation Finance Charlene Watson, ODI, Liane Schalatek, HBS, and Aurélien Evéqu: https://climatefundsupdate.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/CFF3-Adaptation-Finance_ENG-2021.pdf

Clmate-Adapt_ Innovative Financial Instruments for Climate Adaptation: https://napglobalnetwork.org/innovative-financing/
description: Incentives and/or funding can be prerequisites for climate-adaptation work.

name: Number of businesses with risk management plans considering climate change aspects or adaptation options
source: European central Bank (2022) Good practices for climaterelated and environmental risk management. https://www.bankingsupervision.europa.eu/ecb/pub/pdf/ssm.thematicreviewcercompendiumgoodpractices112022~b474fb8ed0.en.pdf

source:
Suggested Impact Reporting Metrics for Climate Change Adaptation Projects
https://www.icmagroup.org/assets/documents/Regulatory/Green-Bonds/Suggested-metrics-for-Climate-Adaptation-projects-with-Reporting-Templates-December-2020-151220.pdf
description: The total sum (in €/$/£) invested in climate-adapted construction and refurbishment over a reporting period

name: Number of properties with retrofitted resilience measures
source:
Key Performance Indicators in Retrofitting Projects: A Review
https://eares.org/siteadmin/upload/1230EAP0518205.pdf

Retrofit Handbook
https://www.nema.gov.au/sites/default/files/2024-12/Retrofit%20Handbook%20%E2%80%93%20Bushfire%20Resilience%20Rating.pdf

Key Performance Indicators for Decision Support in Building Retrofit Planning: An Italian Case Study
https://www.mdpi.com/1996-1073/17/3/559
description: These measures could include: flood resilience, water meters, water efficicency, cooling, etc.

name: Uptake of early warning and disaster preparedness systems
source:
Toolkit for Monitoring & Evaluation of Early Warnings for All
https://www.undrr.org/media/99963/download?startDownload=20250508
description: Number or Percentage of At-Risk Communities with Operational Early Warning Systems

name: Share of permeable surfaces in urban environments
source:
Soil sealing is a comprehensive indicator that characterises aspects of a large number of measures, such as the proportion of green space, structural development and land use (Murata and Kawai2018).Reduced sealing therefore indicates reduced heating of surfaces and increased water permeability, which is important for reducing both heat- and water-related risks (Fokaides et al. 2016) (Source: Patel et al 2025 https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).

Additional sources:

https://doi.org/10.1080/00380768.2018.1439342

https://doi.org/10.1177/1420326x16644495

Luti, T., S. Segoni, F. Catani, M. Munafò, and N. Casagli. 2020. “Integration of Remotely Sensed Soil Sealing Data in Landslide Susceptibility Mapping.”Remote Sensing 12, no.9:1486

https://doi.org/10.1127/metz/2021/1074

García,P., M.E.Pérez, and A.Guerra. 2014. “Using TM Images to Detect Soil Sealing Change in Madrid (Spain).” Geoderma 214–215:135–140
description: Describes the share of permeable surfaces in urban environment, related to risk of pluvial flooding. Can also be related to human comfort during heat.

name: Percentage of coastline under marine protection
source:
Marine protected areas in Europe's seas
https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/indicators/marine-protected-areas-in-europes-seas
description: The proportion of a country’s coastline, marine territorial waters, or Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) that falls within officially designated marine protected areas (MPAs)

name: Share of forested area
source:
Tree cover describes the proportion of the area that is covered by trees or a considerable amount of vegetation. Trees, on the other hand, have more than just positive effects for urban residents. For instance, densely planted trees cool less at night than open meadow areas (Spronken-SmithandOke1999). In addition, tree avenues with canopy closures on busy streets can increase the concentration of air pollutants due to reduced mixing (Venter et al. 2024) (source: Patel et al 2025, https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).

Additional sources:

Spronken-Smith, R.A., and T.R.Oke. 1999. “Scale Modelling of Nocturnal Cooling in Urban Parks.” Boundary-Layer Meteorology 93:287–312.

Venter, Z. S., A. Hassani, E. Stange, P. Schneider, and N. Castell. 2024. “Reassessing the Role of Urban Green Space in Air Pollution Control.” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 121, no. 6: e2306200121. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2306200121.

Meier,F., and D.Scherer. 2012. “Spatial and Temporal Variability of Urban Tree Canopy Temperature During Summer 2010 in Berlin, Germany.” Theoretical and Applied Climatology 110, no. 3: 373–384. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00704-012-0631-0.
description: Ratio of forest area in the unit of analysis under consideration

name: Share of protected natural area
source:
Terrestrial protected areas in Europe
https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/indicators/terrestrial-protected-areas-in-europe
description: Ratio of the area of protected natural sites (NATURA 2000 and CDDA) in the unit of analysis under consideration

name: Share of agricultural area
source:
Land statistics and indicators 2000–2021
https://openknowledge.fao.org/server/api/core/bitstreams/5c8b2707-1bcf-4c29-90e2-3487e583f71e/content
description: Ratio of agricultural area in the unit of analysis under consideration

name: Water needs of crops
source:
simplified crop water balance based on open scientific litterature

https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/maps-and-charts/trend-in-crop-water-deficit/
description: The water needs of a field is assessed by comparing water inputs with plant water use through evapotranspiration. Water inputs refer to rainfall. Evapotranspiration is calculated using a crop coefficient. The soil compartment is not considered in this assessment.

name: Vulnerability of crops to climatic hazards
source: Based on agro-climatic indicators from https://climadiag-agriculture.fr/
description: This indicator takes the form of a toolbox. It can be used to select a crop and highlight the risks associated with the climate at certain key moments in the vegetative development process.

name: Population vulnerability to heat waves
source:
Indicators such as heat-related mortality rates and the heat vul nerability index (HVI) are examples of population vulnerability index. These indexes consider various factors, such as age, health status and mortality due to other diseases, in addition to heat stress for calculation.
However,it is challenging to gather all the data required for the calculation at the city at national level. See Wolf and McGregor (2013, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.wace.2013.07.004) for methodological approach to calculating HVI in their work. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2212094713000054?via%3Dihub

https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/metadata/indicators/vulnerability-to-extremes-of-heat
description: Level of vulnerability of populations to a heat wave aggravated by the potential UHI (urban heat island) effect - Use I1085, I1086, I1087and I1088

name: LCZ vulnerability level
source:
Local climate zones (LCZs) are a classification of a city’s block geometry and land cover in view of the effects on the local urban climate(Jiaetal.2024).The concept of LCZs has contributed to a better understanding and comparability of the intensity of UHI (Stewart and Oke2012),as this concept can be useful for various urban climate or microclimate variables (source: Patel et al 2025 https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).
See:
https://doi.org/10.1007/s11783-017-0984-9
https://doi.org/10.3390/ijgi10080539
https://doi.org/10.3390/su12198083
https://doi.org/10.1109/JSTARS.2012.2189873

https://doi.org/10.3390/su11072032

https://en.institutparisregion.fr/know-how/environment/vulnerability-of-towns-and-cities-to-rising-temperatures-assessed-using-the-local-climate-zones/
description: Vulnerability class of the unit of analysis to urban heat islands in relation to the local climate zone class to which it belongs

name: Share of vulnerable population
source:
https://www.icos-cp.eu/news-and-events/news/european-cities-heatwaves-hit-most-vulnerable

https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/adbcc8/meta
description: Percentage of population sensitive to heat waves (under 5 and over 65 years old)

name: Poverty rate
source:
https://www.icos-cp.eu/news-and-events/news/european-cities-heatwaves-hit-most-vulnerable

https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/adbcc8/meta
description: Rate of low-income households

name: Accessibility to cooling areas
description: Proportion of the population with access to a cooling area nearby (less than 10 minutes' walk)

name: Quality and structure of the green network
source:
https://www.forestresearch.gov.uk/tools-and-resources/fthr/urban-regeneration-and-greenspace-partnership/planning-integrated-landscapes/urban-green-networks-corridors-and-linkages/

description: This index is a weighted sum of most relevant biodiversity indicators such as share of green, canopy and herbaceous area as well as connectivity and distance between canopy areas - Use I1090, I1091, I1092 and I1093

name: Share of green area
source:
The indicator green cover indicates the proportion of public green spaces covering the entire city or a district (with a recommended target of 30%–40%). This 30%–40% of green coverin the form of public and private green spaces would contribute to a significant air temperature reduction in cities. This indicator is calculated using the total area of all green spaces available under the atmospheric canopy in proportion to the total area of land (Patel et al 2025, https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).

Additional sources:
Zhao, C., G. Fu, X. Liu, and F. Fu. 2011. “Urban Planning Indicators,
Morphology and Climate Indicators: A Case Study for a North-South
TransectofBeijing,China.”BuildingandEnvironment46,no.5:1174–1183.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.buildenv.2010.12.009
description: Percentage of the surface area of the unit of analysis occupied by vegetation (private and public spaces combined)

name: Share of canopy area
source:
The urban canopy layer height has a significant effect on UHI. The study done by Zauli Sajani et al. (2008) mentioned that the canopy layer height temperature measurements generally underestimate the values of UHI compared to the 10- and 2- m temperature measurement stations. However, canopy layer height measurements fo rurban climate studies are not common, though they provide significant information for understanding the UHI effects (MaShaoXiuetal.2017) (Patel et al 2025, https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).
Sources:
https://doi.org/10.1007/s00484-008-0171-6
https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/full/10.5555/20183020539

name: Share of herbaceous area
description: Percentage of the surface area of the analysis unit occupied by low vegetation like shrub and grassland (private and public spaces combined)

name: Mean distance between canopy areas
description: Distance as the crow flies between canopy areas and their nearest neighbours in the unit of analysis under consideration

source:

Source
